titlestmt.titleproper: University of Delaware Press collection related to the Cultural Studies of Delaware and the Eastern Shore series 1972-2006
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: University of Delaware Press collection related to the Cultural Studies of Delaware and the Eastern Shore series
did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: The University of Delaware Press was established in the early 1970s and published infrequently until 1975, when it joined the consortium, Associated University Presses. The Press now publishes approximately thirty-five to forty books every year under its own imprint. The Press publishes books in all fields of scholarship, including: literary studies, especially Shakespeare, Renaissance and Early Modern Literature; Eighteenth-Century Studies; French Literature; art history and history; and historical and cultural studies of Delaware and the Eastern Shore.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of publication files, including correspondence, drafts, proofs, and clippings, related to works published as part of the University of Delaware Press - Cultural Studies of Delaware and the Eastern Shore series. The collection includes files for the following titles: Honest John Williams, U. S. Senator and New Sweden in America by Carol Hoffecker; Governing Delaware: Policy Problems by William Boyer; Creek Walking: Growing Up in Delaware in the 1950s by Jacqueline Jones; Hanging the Moon: The Rollins Rise to Riches by Drury Pifer; and Rebel With a Conscience by Russell W. Peterson.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: University of Delaware: Carol Hoffecker papers and William Boyer papers.
